abstract: Far-reaching technological changes are shaping our society and the ways in which we work. A key 21 st-century skill for taking advantage of those changes may be computational thinking (CT). Currently, the great variety in applied measurement instruments is a problem in CT research. This paper aims at providing validity evidence for the 'Computational Thinking Test' (CTt) of Rom치n-Gonz치lez et al. (2017). We use a sample of 202 upper-secondary students from Switzerland. Utilizing item response theory and confirmatory factor analysis, we demonstrate unidimensionality of CTt; differential item functioning and mixed Rasch analyses may indicate the absence of discrimination and thus a fair test instrument. Furthermore, we present a proficiency level model for CTt that allows for a criterion-referenced interpretation of test scores.
